Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), emerged from Wuhan, Hubei province, China, in late 2019 and has now reached pandemic status.
1 Coronaviruses typically cause mild upper respiratory tract infections;
2 however, SARS-CoV-2,
3 severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV),
4 and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV)
5 have all been associated with severe illness and death. Common symptoms reported in adults with COVID-19 are fever, dry cough, and fatigue; severe cases have been associated with dyspnoea and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest CT.
3 In China, the SARS-CoV-2 reproductive number is estimated at 2.
6 The combined case-fatality rate is 2% in China,
7 and the risk of death is increased significantly in older people (approximately 15%).
7 It is noteworthy that infants and children have not been featured prominently in COVID-19 case statistics. An analysis from China has shown that children younger than 10 years account for only 1% of COVID-19 cases,
7 similar to the proportion for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV epidemics. 4, 5
